text:
Rami Rami is drinking a Birth of Tragedy (2016) by Hill Farmstead Brewery at Chmielarnia Marszałkowska

WOW!!! Mega beczkowe w migdalowa strone, slodkie, geste, wyklejajace, waniliowe, kokosowe, miodowe, bombonierka, suszone i kandyzowane owoce

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear dark brown color with an average fizzy tan head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy chocolate malt and roasted coffee with a small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced roasted dark sweet flavor with a medium to heavy dark sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer.

500 ml bottle shared with Tmoney99 and the Nine Giant crew. Pours a dark cola brown color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have big honey sweetness, chocolate, light roast, bourbon, wood, vanilla, brown sugar, molasses, great mouthfeel and body, solid beer as usual.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color porter with a deep brown color head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of coffee with some bourbon notes and nice vanilla notes. Taste is a complex and rich mix of nice vanilla notes with bourbon and rich black chocolate notes and a sweet honey-laced finish. Body is full with deep oily texture and good carbonation with hints of warming alcohol notes. Very rich porter but a bit too much honey for my taste.

500 ml bottle from an IP trade in NYC. Bottle date unreadable, probably relatively fresh. Pours pitch black with a brown head, fairly short retention. Aromas: from the glass its not very strong, a bit woody, sweet, honey-ish, light vanilla and chocolate. Retronasal its stronger, wood, chocolate, sweetness, vanilla, nicely balanced. Flavor is sweet, cocoa, light roast. Alcohol feel is quite strong, warming. Over medium bodied. Long finish with chocolate, light roast and bitterness.

Poured from bottle 2015 vintage thanks Willrunforbeer blackish cola with nice lacing and a mocha head. Aromas of roasted chocolate coffee vanilla caramel and bourbon. Taste is rich creamy luscious mouthfeel caramel vanilla coffee and a nice alcohol finish. Well crafted.

Bottle at tasting. Black pour. Aroma of licorice, booze, honey and cream. Taste has lots of honey, licorice, creamy chocolate, coffee and caramel. Bourbon is subtle, but present. Very balanced and tasty, but more bourbon flavor would make it better, expected even more from this. (perhaps thats the problem)
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. HFD #11 Niezwykle gęste, wyklejające, słodkie. Bourbon, wanilia, czekolada, genialny aromat.

2016 vintage, cracked during Trumps inauguration. This is phenomenally well made. The mouthfeel is full and rich, which brings out the chocolate flavors from the malts and the added coffee, and the bourbon barrel aging adds some aroma and bite without overpowering everything else. Extremely complex, with the porter sweetness, the hop bite, the bourbon aroma, and the spices all coming together to make one mighty fine brew.

Pours a dark brown with carbonated dark brown head. A strong bourbon, coffee, oak and vanilla aroma. A strong flavor of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, liquorice, and vanilla. A lingering dark alcohol and chocolate aftertaste.

Apparence : Presque noire au versement, beau col très foncé, crémeux, bonne rétention, légère dentelle. 
Nez : Dabord, les grains rôtis. Par la suite, on rajoute de la vanille, des notes de chocolat et de café. 
Goût : Chocolat, vanille, malt grillé, alcool, sucre brûlé. Pratiquement toutes les notes du fut de bourbon qui partent et reviennent allégrement. 
Sensation : Corps moyen-plus, crémeuse, léger piquant, belle chaleur en gorge. 
Bref : Tout est joué dans léquilibre, rien dans lexcès. Cette bière est excessivement marquée par ce que le fut de bourbon apporte habituellement à une Stout : du chocolat, de la vanille, un caramel bien grillé, un côté boisé coupant dans le sucre résiduel; beaucoup moins par ses additifs, soit le café et le miel. Cest bon, cest intense, jamais trop sucré. Très belle surprise après la mini déception quavait représenté la Twilight of the Idols. Défaut? Manque un punch peut-être?

Une bière noire sans grande effervescence ni carbonatation. Au nez, on dénote un côté sucré, avec du sucre dorge notamment, de même que laspect torréfié du café utilisé pour brasser la bière. En bouche, on a vraiment limpression davoir affaire avec une bière bien complexe. On remarque dabord le café, avec son goût torréfié mais pas trop intense. Ensuite, on note les goûts plus classiques de la porter avec mélasse et sucre dorge. Enfin le côté plus boisé est présent, avec une impression de sirop dérable intéressante que lon associe au bourbon. Bref, une bière complexe, bien faite.


4

Bottle, picked up at the brewery November 2016. More or less black. Noisy, tan head settles down to a thin, dense, sticky layer. Slow moving and oily. Nose has whisky truffle. Chestnut honey. Milky coffee. Dense, sticky stone fruit. Lots of date, prune and fig. Taste is stone fruit sweet, with a vinous, tangy dryness. Mouthfeel is rich and full, although a bit too fizzy to suit. Vinous, chocolatey, coffee rich finish. Very nice, if a little sweet, for me.

Tasting at Alexs. 500ml, bottled on 21-Sep-2016 (thx, Higo V.!). Pours an almost black with a dark beige head. Aroma is bourbon barrels, some sour berries notes, roasted malt. Taste is the same with some very slight coffee. Surpusingly very drinkable with almost no boozy notes. Just perfect.

Bottle. - Sweet dark bourbon and dark bourbon. Jet black with a rich brown head, Tons barrel notes and sweet bourbon with a long fruity dark sweet finish. Better than the nose which I found a little hot.

500ml bottle shared with Sam and Julien. Pours jet black. Small light foamy mocha head leaving a small lacing. Smells of small coffee roasts, strong cinnamon and slight vanilla and sweet honey and bourbon smoothness and booziness. Love it. Tastes of vanilla smoothness and cinnamon to boot on the start and a great roastiness at the end. Really love this beer. Sweet bourbon and honey combo at the end. Wonderful full mouthfeel leaving a full and delicious aftertaste. Really, really amazing.

Birth of tragedy 
Pours a dark brown with a khaki lacing ap 4. 
Aroma: 8/9huge notes of chocolate syrup soy sauce, vanilla and alcohol

F: sweet but not cloying 8/9

P: on nitro so creamy 

Ov 18/19

Thanks Dr. Moll for sharing the bottle! Poured into a snifter showing black center with thin coffee brown rims and half a finger of dark latte foam. 

The nose shows a strong mix of roasted malts and burnt black coffee. 

The palate is moderately carbonated and medium bodied. Caramel malt forward with a light latte with burnt and toasted bitter notes.

2015 bottle, if I remember correctly, drunk 10/21/16, thanks to Nelson.Deep, dark, impenetrable ebony body is topped by a medium-sized, tan head showing strong retention.Much less spice comes through in this than Twilight, which is good as I thought last years batch of that was overspiced, not terribly so, but still somewhat. Low on the barrel aging with no big oakiness and predominantly spicy bourbon notes without any sharp, boozy edges. What it certainly does have is malt. Lots of it. Rich, fudgey malts are full and aromatic with roasted barley acidity helping to balance. Light soy, maple and chalky, yeast notes with vanilla and fudge lingering.Rich, velvety and sweet, it has low but tight carbonation and low spicing. The bourbon adds spicy liquor notes which help offset this huge maltiness. Furthermore, the finish is full of roasted acidity, creating luxurious coffee flavors and balancing the beer. It still tends sweet, of course, but importantly doesnt seem in the least bit syrupy or cloying, and Im very sensitive to too much sweetness.

(On tap @ Warpigs HF Day, Copenhagen, May 12 2016) Pours pitch black with a pale tan head and light lace. Aroma is rich with fairly heavily roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, toasted coconut, spicy undertones, some oak, hint of booze. Flavour is rather concentrated and sweet to begin, dark chocolate, coffee, bourbon, dried fruit, cinnamon, vanilla, toffee, rather roasted, drying towards the finish with woody notes, bitter coffee and deep roast more apparent, a touch earthy with alcohol warmth. Full bodied and silky with low carbonation. Pretty bourbon heavy but holds itself up with spices and a roasty core, really drinkable stuff if perhaps more suited to winter weather.
From tap at Warpigs. Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, oak, alcohol, licorice, dark fruit, chocolate and coffee.

500ml bottle from trade with Jeffrey shared with brother. Aroma: strong coffee and coffee, roasted malt. Oh and of course bourbon. App: dark brown, minimal brown head leaving minimal brown head. Taste and palate: medium to full body, creamy but still liquoreux, subtle bitter finish. Overall: well this is good. Really good. Like the mouthfeel quite a lot. Something I wish I would have drank during this winter. Really good and easy to drink.

2013 bottle. Pitch black pour, 1 finger of offwhite head, minimal lacing. Whiskey up front in the aroma, black coffee, honey, roasted malt. Bourbon gives way to black coffee, liquid honey, roasted malt, vanilla, dark toffee, wood. Medium body, incredibly smooth after the unintentional aging.

Tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Poured a clear dark brown with a thin broken tan head. The aroma is big sweet malt, spicy Christmas pudding, alcohol. The flavour is moderate sweet with a smooth rich alcoholic, earthy malt, coffee, light chocolate plate. Full bodied with flat carbonation.

On tap at Warpigs. Near black with mocca head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, coconut, vanilla and bourbon. Taste is similar and has roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, coconut with a warming finish
[5/12/16] Draught at Warpigs in Copenhagen. Black. Aroma of chocolate, roast, licorice, a bit of dark fruits. Sweet flavor with chocolate, cocoa, roast, coffee, licorice and dark fruits. Full-bodied.

Draught @ Hill Farmstead Day - Warpigs Brewpub, København
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, alcohol, bourbon, vanilla, coffee and oak. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, oak and bourbon finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

From tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Black color with beige brown head. roasted malty aroma, caramel, chocolate, coffee, licorice, some spicy perfume notes - peppermint, wood, alcohol. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium to full oily silky body with soft carbonation.

Tap @ Warpigs. Very dark brown with tiny head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, coconut and bourbon. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, coconut, little vanilla, warming, medium sweet, hop and medium bitter.

On tap at Warpigs, pre-CBC. Pitch black with a tan head. Smells of bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, chocolate, toasted coconut. Medium body with a bitter-sweet aftertaste.

Bottle @ Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, dark chocolate, wood, light bourbon, vanilla, alcohol. Flavor is sweet, rich malty, caramel, light spice, vanilla, chocolate, wood, bourbon, alcohol. Medium body, average carbonation, oily mouthfeel, sweet finish with warming alcohol. 120516
Draught at Warpigs during Hill Farmstead takeover. Deep chocolate bourbon notes. Some coffee. Rich.

12.05.2016, tap @ Warpigs:
Nice light brown creamy shortlasting head. Aroma is slightly dry boozy, bourbon, minerals, burnt caramel, dark malts, grass, oak, bark, caramel, dark sugar, coffee, licorice, dark fruits. Taste is slightly sour-ish dry, dark malts, dark fruits, minerals, oak, alcohol, dark sugar, licorice, caramel, chocolate, mild bourbon, vanilla. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mineraly mouthfeel. Nice enough.
Tap @Warpigs. Black, small light beige head. Aroma has wood and bourbon. Wood, bourbon, roast and caramel flavour. Perhaps some dark choc. Perfectly balanced and very sippable. Awesome.
Tap 21...Keg at war pigs... Dark black... Thin tan lacing.. Dark chocolate roast.. Big roast nose.. .. Big meaty .. Very big berries chocolate roast... Rich chocolate roast

Draught. Almost black coloured. Dense black head. Aroma. Alcohol, sweetness, spice, roast, flavour. Roast, cocoa, chocolate, alcohol, spice. Medium to full bodied. Ends roasted bitter with lads of alcohol warmth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at warpigs. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, liquorice and dried fruits. Boozy notes. Spicy. The flavours starts sweet but finish bitter. Great.

From tap at Warpigs, Hill Farmstead Day. Its a jet black beer with a small beige head. Boozy and roasted aroma with notes of coffee and oak. Light vanilla. Sweet roasted flavor with bourbon and vanilla notes. Light coffee. Quite sweet overall. Great.
Bottle at Warpigs. Aroma is cinnamon and cocoa. Taste is cinnamon, cocoa, slight roast, a hint of coffee, caramel sweet, mild coconut.

Pours black with a very low tan head. Aromas of milk chocolate, roasted almonds, vanilla, brown sugar. Immensely well balanced on the nose. Taste is ridiculously! Milk chocolate, roasted barrel notes and sweet maltiness blended to absolute perfection. I do not want to swallow this, want to keep it in my mouth forever. Mouthfeel is luxuriously velvety and smooth. Holy goat this is awesome!

Pours dark with low tanned head 
Aromas lovely of molasses, bourbon, vanilla, coffee, fudge, 
Taste brilliant of bourbon, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, molasses, caramel 
Mouthfeel brilliantly balanced with creamy, velvety smooth and warming alcohol notes
On tap at Warpigs. Black with a minimal white head. Aroma of licorice, mint and alcohol. Sweet candy-like flavour of licorice and chocolate with notable alcohol. There is a spicy wooden note.

Tap@ warpigs. Pours near black with a thin brown head. Slightly boozy, dark fruity nose, plums, dates mostly. Sweet plummy, oaky, dark fruity flavor. balanced sweetness, plummy, some chocolate. Sweet lingering finish. Wood quite strongly. Good sipper.

bottle shared with Kermis.
Thin ring tan head. Coffee boubon aroma and aftertaste. Clear black pour. Some honey too

Bottle shared with Paul at Hills tasting room. Pours a deep brown body with tan lacing. Nose is cinnamon brownie. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with notes of cinnamon sugar, brownie, soft roast and sweet chocolate. Super decadent and very enjoyable imperial porter verging on stout.

Bottle pours out black topped with a tan head. Nose is roast malts chocolate coffee some herbal notes molasses bourbon barrel. Taste is more of the sweetness roast malts chocolate coffee vanilla milk chocolate and a nice rich bourbon barrel end.

November 3, 2015. Bottle at home, bottled october 2013. Received in a trade with Leighton, thanks!
Black with a small, quite fizzy, brown head. Aroma is plum, bourbon, sherry, dried fruits, milk chocolate, notes of coffee, vanilla, charred wood and a touch of cinnamon. Taste is sweet dark fruits with a soft bitterness. Finish is sweet with plum, vanilla, milk chocolate, hints of figs, soft bitter with notes of cold pressed coffee and light roastiness. Medium to full bodied, very soft small bubble carbonation, creamy, oily texture. 

 
Very good and quite complex imperial porter with subtle barrel notes. Perhaps on the sweeter side, could do with just a touch more bitterness in the finish.

Bottle shared. Pours black with a ring beige head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, fudge, caramel, chocolate, malt, light coffee and spicy peppery notes. Flavour is light heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Light full bodied with a slightly thick mouthfeel, alcohol warmth and soft carbonation.

Bottle shared thanks to Hallinghansen in the line for Blåbær Release 2015. Pours a pitch black with a small, tan head. Aroma has lots of bourbon, but in a slightly different way. More minty and fruity. Roasted malts and caramel. Taste is very sweet, lots of oak, complex, different malt profile. COffee roasty bitter finish. Sticky body and low carbonation. Not bad!

Birth of tragedy 15 vintage

Pours a night black color, with a decent beige head, which collapses to formable swirls of lacing, coating up the side of the glass.

Consists of a nose, which comes beautifully together, defined by earthy coffee, toffee malts, coconut and oaky, warm Bourbon. All the different aromas stand out on their own, while blending flawlessly together, with wild honey on top, adding a glazed, sweet aspect to the mix. Bourbon is certainly noteable, while not over the top at all, accentuating the other aspects of the beer.

Drinks amazingly smooth and fairly easy, based on its actual abv, while its lower carbonation opens up the palate to sweet honey very effectivly. Doesnt have a thick mouthfeel as bcbs, while it drinks almost smoother.

There is toffee, earthy, bitter coffee, gently wrapped up by wood embraced Bourbon, coconut and wild honey to complete the taste. I am honestly blown away by the outstanding balance of this, while every flavor is easily recognizable on its own, they all seem to benefit from each other, by enhancing each others appearance on the palate. The Bourbon provides a pleasant warmth during the beers finish, easily balanced by slick honey, producing a melting caramel, glazed sugar impression, adding to the toffee, creating the most enjoyable, natural sweetness you could ever wish for.

A real treat, much more than I expected it to be. The flavors come beautifully together, tied together by a balance and smoothness which almost puts Bourbon County to shame, and that at a considerable lower abv. Honey and Bourbon create a incredibly synergy, making up for the lack of roastieness by providing the most enjoyable sweetness I experienced in a beer so far, which makes this perfect for a cold winter night, as well as for every other night in which you want to drink an exeptional beer.

Bottle (dated 10/2013). Pours black with an ample mocha head that eventually fades to a 1/4 ring around the glass, where it stays until its gone. Smells of bourbon, roasted malts, oak, some alcohol apparent after it warms. A medium+ sweetness balanced by a medium bitterness. Tastes of chocolate, coffee, light bourbon. Full bodied; thick and lightly creamy; below average carbonation. Really a wonderful mouthfeel. Moderately bitter finish. An exceptional beer.

Dun noir sans équivoque, une mousse brunâtre pas très généreuse se pose doucement sur la bière. De la vanille, du chocolat au lait, du nougat, un peu de bois imbibé dalcool, cest définitivement un bouquet qui me plaît. Heureusement, lidylle se répète en bouche, ces saveurs étant enveloppées dune chaleur alcoolisée et sucrée réconfortante. Une texture veloutée qui me fait fondre à chaque gorgée. Je me visualise dans un chalet, sur le bord dun feu ardent, par une froide soirée dhiver à siroter ce nectar divin. Superbe.

Thanks Shawn! Pours a very dark ruby, almost black color with little to no head. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, bourbon, roasted malts, booze and doughy bread. Taste is a little muted on the aroma, which isnt bad, as I do not pick up much detection of alcohol. Medium mouthful, silky smooth, easy drinking for the high ABV. Could use a little more carbonation. Overall, excellent beer!

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2015 Bottle @ bells 30th pre party, aroma is bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, and malts, taste is out of this world chocolate, vanilla, borbon, soy, some sweetness and oak, damn, doesn?t get much better than this!!!
Black with a light brown head. Faint vanilla, bourbon notes, a bit flat in the end and in dimensional

500 mL bottle poured into a snifter. 2011 bottle. Originally reviewed 3/15/2013. Viscous black with brown edges. No head. Big mocha bubbles, though. Bourbon and coffee blend nicely in the nose. Vanilla. The coffee has a nice earthy character. Not a lot of porter comes through, but it doesnt matter much. Nice bourbon and vanilla flavors. Lots of coffee. Reminiscent of KBS in its earthy coffee flavor. Milk chocolate with a slight winey finish.
 Heavy. Viscous for a porter, although thats arguable. Very low carbonation.
So it isnt as magical as I had hoped, but its still damn good. Remarkably good, but the bar that Hill Farmstead has set for itself makes me feel the slightest disappointment when the beer isnt perfection.

Bottle in line for blåbær. Thanks for the sample to MrOrla. Pours black with an espresso head. Aroma of dark fruits, wood, chocolate, vanilla, syrup and nice coffee. Taste of chocolate, vanilla, syrup, coffee, wood and weak spices. Very good and balanced!
Bottle in line for Blåbær 15. Pitch black pour with a tan head. Loads of sweet chocolate, coffee, some cinnamon with some lightly roasted notes.

Bottle thanks to MrOrla. Thanks! Pours pitch black with a medium dark brown head. Aromas of honey cake, cinnamon, malts, vanilla, dark fruits, dark chocolate. Complex and very nice aroma. Taste is honey cake, coffee, bourbony vanilla, fudge and cinnamon notes, dark filled chocolates, malt.
Bottle at blåbær release 2015. Black body with a small brown head. Chocolate, green peppers, bourbon, vanilla, wood. Soo good.
Blåbær street tasting 2015. Pours pitch black with brown head. Aroma of wood, burbon, very sweet, peppery notes, caramel, choko, coffe. Taste is peppery, vanili, choko, burbon, Extreme sweet.

Bouteille 500ml. Couleur noire opaque, mousse moka foncée laissant un anneau sur les parois du verre et une dentelle épaisse mais éparse. Arôme boisé, Bourbon, noisette, malt torréfié, cendre. Goût boisé, alcool, malt torréfié, chocolat noir, sucré. Carbonatation très faible, corps moyen.

Bottle shared by a friend. Darkest brown pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, chocolate and molasses. Malty flavor with dark fruit before a chocolatey finish. Not picking up on the coffee, spice or barrel. Still tasty though.

500ml bottle bought from brewery. Pours black, almost no head. Aromas of oak and bourbon, light coffee and roasted malt notes follow. Taste is semi sweet. Flavors of bourbon, roast, some toast, slightly vinous. kind of scraggly. A touch too sweet, not enough carb. Kind of mediocre for this brewery. Meh. Not worth $20.

Merci à SlovakSniper pour avoir partagé ce moment de dégustation avec moi. Bière bien noire affichant un collet qui ma surpris pour une bière de ce type. En effet, un fort collet sombre de grosses bulles sest rapidement formé en surface de ce liquide noir mais sa durée de vie fut toutefois courte. Nempêche, tant la mousse que la pré-mousse (jappelle ainsi les fines bulles situées sous la mousse principale qui collent aux parois du verre) annonçaient un liquide riche et onctueux, Nez léger. Surprise! Même en plongeant agressivement mon nez au fond de mon verre (petit verre étroit et plutôt long destiné à la dégustation des vins de porto) je ne détectais pas les arômes complexes que je mattendais à y trouver. Le bois certes, le café (bien entendu) et quelques fruits et des violettes de sus-bois. En se réchauffant par contre, le liquide gagnait du nez. De chaudes vapeurs dalcool et de fruits rouges émanaient de mon verre. en bouche, le tout était très léger et agréable. Encore une surprise. La rondeur anticipée nétais pas au rendez-vous. Bière à la texture très soyeuse et souple, mais de corps moyen. Des flaveurs de vanille, de prune et de fraises. De durée moyenne en bouche et dune texture dune grande délicatesse, cette bière est fort agréable mais nest pas à mon avis une Grande parmi les Grandes.

Merci à Youri pour lhospitalité et pour la dégustation! Vintage 2015. Au versement, le corps brun très foncé est entouré dune lumière pourpre. La tête mousseuse est bien belle au départ mais tombe assez rapidement. Je ne vois pas de dentelle sur mon verre. Au nez, le bourbon est caramélisé, vanillé et teinté par la noix de coco. Tout est bien (ou trop) doux et un peu éloigné de ce que je mattends ordinairement dun porter impérial. En fait, les parfums sont riches et annoncent beaucoup de sucre en bouche. Sur les papilles, je décèle rapidement des saveurs de bois brûlé (lintérieur du fût de bourbon). Les sucres annoncés ne sont pas tant au rendez-vous : la douceur est contenue par leau-de-vie. En se tempérant, par contre, tout devient un peu plus collant. En bouche, le liquide est bien soyeux. Les bulles sont modérées à faibles. La finale est de plus en plus chaude et aussi assez douce : le sucre des dernières gorgées se loge aux commissures de mes lèvres. Tout compte fait, beau nez riche mais moyennement complexe et saveurs un peu obnubilées par le caractère noirci du fût. Ceci dit, bon porter impérial qui nest certainement pas, en ce qui me concerne, fabuleux. Je cite ici le camarade madmitch76 qui, avec cette phrase, résume très bien mon expérience : «Lacks a wow factor and thus not in the highest echelons».

Aroma: Smooth Bourbon, Cinnamon, Mild Vanilla, Mild Honey

Appearance: Dark Hue, Passes Almost No Light, Thin Off White Head Ring, Some Lacing

Taste: Vanilla, Cinnamon, Mild Chardomum, Mild Coffee

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet
Bottle, fresh, pour is black with low tan head. Aroma is bourbon, pal, roast, chocolate. Taste is bourbon and oak that gives to roast, and a light sweet and floral roast finish.

Pour is pitch black black cola with zero head. Nose is interesting combo of porter and barleywine. Roasted malts, cola, horse feed grains, maple syrup, vanilla, molasses. Deceivingly thin, refreshingly thin actually. Nice balance of sweet, graininess, and roastiness. Taste is surprisingly good. Subtle balance of porter and barrel goodness. Roasted malts, cola, maple syrup, molasses, cereal grains, vanilla. It's a clean drinkable barrel aged porter. Not too sweet, not to burndiness.
Pour from bottle. Black, tan head. Aroma is strong mix of chocolate, roast, booze, rich. Taste is smooth, hint of sweetness, chocolate. Dont get the bourbon, but super tasty.

Shared 50cl bottle by a friend. 2013 version. Poured a dark black colour with a tanned head. Sweet caramel, honey, dark roasted coffee, cacao, sweet chocolate, vanilla, small bourbon notes, lots of dark chocolate, perfectly balanced with the bourbon. Not overwelming but just enough. Amazingly complex brew. Again one great beer from Hill farmstead! Man i love their beers

Sampled from bottle (2013 vintage) shared by Countbeer. Thanks Kamiel! Opaque pitch black color, medium sized dark brown colored head that lasts for a decent while. Aroma is malts, bourbon, a hint of sweetness, slightly a hint of coffee. Taste malts, dark fruits, dark malts, lightly roast, softly bitter and the slightest hint of liquorice. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle (50cl): Shared with Benzai: Vintage 2013: Thanks to PhillyCraft for trading this gem: Served in a Chouffe glass at roomtemperature:
Black beer with a medium sized creamy beige light brown head.
Aromas of vegetables with honey, roast, spices (cloves, ginger...) and some fruit. Also some coffee, raisin and toffee.
Flavours of roast, honey, mocha, malt roast drenched in soy, some brown sugars but its not sweet, nice bitter, some nuts and leaf roast, light cough syrup... Smooth!
Aftertaste is a mix of bitters, spices, cough syrup, some honey and roast.
Low carbo, mouthfeel, medium to full bodied.
Smooth and balanced, delicious stuff! 11%ABV? Thought it was approx 7,5/8% well done!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
How: Bottle.
Where: Traded.
Appearance: Black colour with a brown head.
Aroma: Chocolate, spices, coffee, raisin, alcohol, caramel.
Body: Full body, low to medium carbonation.
Flavour: Coffee, spices, vanilla, alcohol, chocolate.

nice beer, shared with swoopjones out of his fantastic cellar. thank you. dark pour, nose is dark malts and bourbon. mouthfeel is big, really smooth. flavous are great, hits every note you would want on a BB aged porter!
bottle, amazing porter. jet black pour, fuller bodied. lots of roasted maltiness, coffee, bourbon notes. complex, yet incredibly smooth. awesome
At my place with Garrett on a chill Friday night. Aroma is booze gooey brownie. Taste is tasty smooth cocoa smooth booze. Such a fantastic beer. great smooth brownie flavor. Love.
Bottle thanks Phil. Black pour with tan head. Sweet chocolate, spice, coffee and vanilla aromas. Chocolate, vanilla, coffee flavors, touch of bourbon and spice tones.

Hill Farmstead Birth of Tragedy - bottled Oct. 2013. 

Opaque; near black with a modest, sudsy head that has good retention. 

Overall nearly on par with FW Parabola consumed just beforehand. Compared to Parabola, this was sweeter, had less coffee, and was smoother. 

O: Rich but easy to drink and very well balanced. Tastes and feels more aged than just 1 year.

Bottle shared at Browns. Thanks, Nick! Pours nearly black with a bright golden brown head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, tart dark fruits, cereal. Taste has darkchocolate, plenty of roast, bourbon, vanilla. Some coconut flavor in here that doesnt quite belong. As it warms, the coconut disappears and is replaced by more prominant boubon and oak.
There was some coffee, not so much bourbon because the whole IP was so balanced and tasty and drinkable. One of the best porters I have had. Thanks Tomtom for the hookup.Thick mouthfeel.
Nom nom nom thanks Kahn this is good stuff. Black and delicious. I want more. Gimmie gimmie gimmie

Bottle shared with Mane Liquor lads :) Pours a black with a small beige head. Nose is coconut! Like a coconut has wacked you in the face. Milk chocolate and earthiness add to the nose. SO much coconut - El described this as a smoked ham with coconut. Fair bit of bourbon, dry cocoa and shit loads of coconut and molasses. Vanilla sweetness rounds it off. Fucking world class

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2014 Bottle with a huge thanks to King Leighton. Pours black with little head. Nose is a big bang of coconut! Absolutely in-your-face coconut with dusty milk chocolate and a nice robust earthiness to it. I love coconut so Im definitely enjoying this one. Taste is like a bourbony lamington - loads of dry & dusty cocoa, plenty of coconut, molasses and vanilla. Almost a little dirty and I like it a lot. Coconut-centric. Very classy beer

Darkish brown with a tan head. Aroma is bourbon, liquorice, touch of vegetal. Full bodied, smooth mouthfeel, sweet on the palate. Taste is bourbon, dates, prunes, honey, very subtle hint of green pepper.

Bottle shared with the epic. Aroma is chocolate truffle, espresso, burnt honey, and vanilla. Pours black and thick with a small dark brown film on top. Taste follows suit with roast coffee, honey covered chestnut, chocolate truffle, and vanilla oak. Nice thick mouthfeel but not too sweet or roasty. The honey and barrel lend to this rather than overpower it. I am almost mad that one brewery can make so much good beer.

Bottle via trade. Nose has an earthy, dirty, fruitiness to it. Pour is pitch black with a huge light brown head. Trying to find the coffee in the nose but it just isnt there. Taste reveals more chocolate and cocoa, but still not coffee. only a slight vanilla note and alcohol warming (maybe beer, maybe barrel). A light cherry note as it warms. Definitely a lot of boost in this beer.

Bottled 10/2013. 
Aroma has moderate chocolate and medium light honey notes with some light roast. Some dark fruit esters, sweet berries and plums. Medium light coffee notes with some nuttiness and toffee. Light alcohol spice and bourbon notes. 
Pours black with a medium small, fairly thick mocha head with some reddish hues. Head recedes fairly quickly to the edges. Light lacing and fairly long legs. 
Flavor has some moderate sweetness with quite a bit of chocolate character. Moderate honey notes and light roast character. Moderate sweet berry, cherry and plum notes. Medium light bourbon and oak notes - both are fairly prevalent but not hot at all. Very light coffee character. Medium light bitterness with a touch of alcohol in the finish. Some toffee and caramel as it warms along with a touch more roast. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium carbonation and a somewhat silky mouthfeel that ends with some stickiness. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, an amazingly enjoyable porter with some great complexity. The really impressive thing for me is how the bourbon and oak notes interact without being too hot. The coffee notes are somewhat muted, but add some slight complexity without dominating. Honey adds a good character that works well with the bourbon notes.

With the crew and in conjunction with Twighlight, nice call to pair these together westmeister. The barrel adds some vanilla. The base beer is still recognizable on the back end with some roasty malt and bittersweet coffee. Syrupy sweet finish. A little more body and an extra point for the barrel since it complements and adds so well.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2014 Recd in a trade and shared with the crew. Had this directly after Twilight of Idols for a horizontal type of thing. Liked this a bit better. The bourbon is subtle from a booze aspects but comes in a really sweet, vanilla, and a touch of oak. Coffee is still just an undertone. Overall, all smooth, nice palate, and I could sip all day.

500 ml. bottle. Pours almost black with just the hint of a brown head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, bourbon, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, bourbon, coffee, vanilla, spice, and wood. Very warming. Very nice.
this one kinda underwhelmed me, for my first taste of HF. will have to see how some of the others are.
Really excellent. Nicely done flavor of coffee bitterness with super smooth palate and little to no heat from the barrels.

On tap at the Harvest festival. Pitch black with small mocha bubbles as foam. Rich chocolate, coffee aroma with some strong bourbon vanilla notes. Some spices too. Very sweet but the roastiness from the coffee makes it more dry and drinkable. Low carbonation. This is a decadent beer, a sipper for sure. I tried the next batch in bottles and it was less decadent and more "fortified". Both were different but equally good.

Bottle from a trade with Mathiec, thank you sir. My first Hill Farmstead, and my 700th rating. Pours a true opaque, with a dark khaki head that is about a finger and dies to nothing as quick as it appears. No lace. Nose sweet roasty malt, some barrel character. Tastes a little boozy heat, some bitterness, vanilla, bourbon is light, mainly hot though. I like it, looking forward to trying more from these guys.

Bouteille de 500 ml, édition 2013. Arômes de bourbon, de café froid et de malts torréfiés. Robe noire et opaque, effervescence assez faible et légère dentelle moka. En bouche, les épices (cannelle) sont plus présentes quau nez. On note également de douillets malts chocolatés et une belle présence de café froid. Lapport du fût de chêne est bien dosé. La texture est particulièrement bien réussie et rend cette bière plutôt facile à boire malgré son ampleur. Finale assez douce. Lalcool est très peu présent. Très bon!

Small growler filled from bottle. Thx Mathieu87!
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, little to no beige head.
NOSE: alcohol, coffee, mocha, vanilla.
TASTE: alcohol, coffee, toffee.

Bottle (9% ABV). An opaque pitch black beer, with an average sized, frothy, lightly lacing, mostly lasting brown head. The aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, coffee, chocolate, caramel), with strong notes of vanilla, coconut, whiskey and wood, other notes of alcohol, dried fruits and cinnamon. Medium to full body, velvety/oily texture, soft carbonation, very long finish with light to moderate bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Intense and amazing barrel nose, yet "beery" enough. Alcohol is pretty well hidden and it achieves the result of not being sticky/syrupy.

Bottle. Not sure if 2012 or 2011. Black as soy sauce pour with the same amount of carbonation. Nose of light roast, faint coffee, and faint vanilla and booze. Taste is slightly heavier on the roast. Flat as all shit but the taste isn't too bad. Was so looking forward to this, and you can tell it has a lot of good qualities, but the lack of any carbonation is just too much to overcome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle (2012 vintage) pours dark rick black-brown with a finger of mocha head. Nose is dusty roast cocoa, subtle coffee grounds, dark fruit, plum, mellow bourbon. Taste is silky smooth and creamy roast dark cocoa and coffee, almond, coconut, vanilla, sublte fruity plum notes from the bourbon. Finish is vanilla and fruity roast coffee, faint oakiness, subtle spice, and mild warmth. Barrel and bourbon character is perfectly balanced. Fantastic.

Black colour, tan head. Aroma of vanilla, lots of vanilla. Coffee, light honey, roasted malts, caramel and warm bourbon notes. Sweet flavour, vanilla, coffee, rather bitter. Finish chocolate, vanilla, lingering bitterness. Nice enough.
(From 50cL bottle @ the pre-RBBWG get-together at Tims place. Thanks for sharing, Seba!!)

Bottle thanks to Minh. Pours a dark brown with beige head that leaves sticky lacing along the glass the aroma is roast, booze, chocolate, and oak. Medium mouthfeel with rich malt and roast with nuttiness and toffee. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2014 [Bottle / 2012] Thanks, Jason! Black-ish body with some deep, deep brown only at the edges, capped with a small, tan-tinted layer of foam that quickly secedes to a chunky collar. Wow... lovely aroma on this one. Fancy coffee beanery type coffee beans, slight malt roast, a mild touch of sweet smoke, & delicate bittersweet cocoa nibs all layered over a smooth backdrop of wood, oak, & whiskey. Layered well, opens up even more with some warmth... Hints of vanilla & tannins. Flavor has a larger whiskey soaked oak presence but remains smooth as hell. Clashing cocoa & coffee beans, leaning towards sweet with a slight roasted malt bitterness for balance. Finish has some vanilla, faint dark fruits & the aftertaste leaves your mouth coated with rich coffee beans, whiskey, & mild oak. Lovely mouth feel; chewy, robust, quite thick... Seriously awesome stuff. Everett may be the best porter Ive had & this may be the best barrel aged porter Ive had. Damn Hill Farmstead.

2012 bottle. Thanks Tom! Shared at Jeffs. Pours almost black with a small head that fades to a thin ring. Awesome aroma, heavy coffee and bourbon, some light chocolate and spices too. Taste is smooth coffee and bourbon with hints of honey, tobacco, and chocolate. Medium body. Mouthfeel is pretty slick and it coats the palate. Awesome beer with a great barrel treatment.

Courtesy of umich03jm
Bottle: The aroma consists of chocolate, coffee, vinous notes, bourbon, faint alcohol, and a touch of oak. It pours a dark brown with some faint Orange highlights and a small beige head that quickly fades to a thin ring around the edge of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate milk chocolate and a touch of cola. The finish has maple syrup, roasted coconut, coffee, and a touch of molasses. Its medium-full bodied with mild carbonation.

Bouteille 50cl via trade. Anno 2012.
Noire, col moka quasi absent.
Arôme est centré à fond sur les malts, caramel, léger boisé sur des notes de bourbon et qcq effluves de vanille.
Palais est malté, profond, super au niveau bourbon, pointe boisée ajoutant cette petite note épicée. Caramel avec une effervescence à la ramasse, ce qui ne joue pas vraiment en faveur de la bière. Donne des notes sucrées, léger collant aux lèvres, résiduel boisé avec qcq notes vanillées. Ressent un léger picotement en fin de bouche, avec au final un bon profil du malt, chocolat et bourbon. Ok, mais après avoir dégusté dautres Hillfarm, je mattendais à mieux.

Pitch black, huge brown head. Super intense aromas of red wine at first, then bourbon, spicy, herbaceous. Big bold smooth velvety body, low carbonation, very silky, chocolate liquor, red wine again, feeling like a young bordeaux rive gauche with hints of roasted meat, vanilla and grilled toasts ! Absolutely intense and delicious.

Almost black, opaque, thin mocha head. Black coffee, chocolate, bourbon, charred oak, some vanilla, and cinnamon undertones. Honey comes out in the taste, sweeter and richer. Creamy, fairly viscous, and full-bodied without being too heavy. Little to no alcohol presence in the clean finish.

2011 bottled and cellared. Opened two years after purchasing from the brewery. Oil black, no head, reminiscent of Baltic porters without the carbonation. Nose from the barrel aging, alcohol, coffee, burnt toffee, etc. Taste is the same, BIG alcohol finish burn like port. Overdid it with the cellaring, should have opened last year.

The beer is near black with an inch of dense, beige foam atop the beer. Looks thick and a bit viscous. Fabulous aroma. Honey emerges more than coffee. Grandiose and lovely honey presence in both the scent and flavor. Beautiful blend of flavors here. Roast and honey marry up to form a slightly sweet, chocolaty beer with just enough bittering hops to balance it all out. Silky smooth on the palate. Long lasting aftertaste. Bourbon character is subtle. This beer is all about balance. If any one ingredient stands out, it is certainly the honey. Yet another fabulous brew from Hill Farmstead.

Black with good, creamy, chocolate shake head, light lacing (barrel-aged) / Deep nose of tobacco, roast grain, dark chocolate / Full body, rich and chewy, some sweetness but excellent balance, good bitterness lurking underneath, alcohol well masked / Big, complex flavors of prune, date, dark roast coffee, semisweet chocolate, tobacco, licorice, honey, faint bourbon barrel / Spectacular, raising the oft-asked question of the difference between in imperial porter and stout.

This one poured a dark brown almost black with a beige head. Aroma was chocolate, coffee, honey and bourbon. Flavor was very well melded together, lots of milk chocolate, coffee, honey like, bourbon, Incredible smooth.
Bottle shared thanks to beerman6686. Pours a deep black with a minimal tan head. Aroma of bourbon, cinnamon, some coffee and chocolate. Sweet taste. Medium thick body. Light carb.
2013 Bottle shared thanks to Beerman6686. Poured pitch black with light tan head. Pleasant aroma of light bourbon and ends with roasted cashew indian. Light carb med bod. Toasty grape choc taste.

2013 Bottle, thanks Gerrit and Drew for the share: Pitch black with tan frothy head. The aroma has notes of licorice, bourbon, roast, smoke, rye bread and herbal hop esters. The taste is heavy with initial dark fruit and anise along with an interesting grapey acidic counterpoint. Earthy, charred, coffee and a bit bready as well. The mouth feel is aggressive and biting with an ashy finish. This is very nice.

Bouteille 500mL (embouteillée 2013). Noire opaque, avec mousse légère. Nez peu expressif, vanille et traces de café. Bouche soyeuse: vanille, café, un côté épicé qui rappelle la canelle mais sans en avoir le côté piquant, un côté mielleux assez dominant, bourbon. Le tout est incroyablement équilibré et doux. Rien naccroche et on ne goûte pas lalcool. Encore une réussite!

2013 bottle thanks to Dany. Very dark pour. Slight tan head. Aroma oddly enough has a slight moacatel or white wine smell. Or possibly some wild yeast. Almost like it is infected by some of the farmhouse yeast but in a good way. Taste has a very slight very mellow bourbon. Lots of sweetness probably from the honey. Some roast an coffee. Everything is very mellow and balanced. Tasty stuff.

Poured black with minimal tan head.
On the nose bourbon and chocolate.
On the tongue huge hints of bourbon and dark toasty malts. This is delicious!!!!!

Dunkel malziger, etwas zu süßer Antrunk. Honignoten, passend alkoholisch, dann Noten von Bourbon, im Mittelteil kurzzeitig milder werdend. Kaffee hinter der Süße, intensiv, auch im Abgang noch zu süß. 10/12/8/11/12/11

Thanks to Jason for this! Pours near pitch black/brown with a brown head. The smell is coffee, bourbon, dark malt, licorice. The taste is bourbon, coffee, licorice, some honey at the end with a touch of alcohol. Full bodied and elegantly carbonated. Amazing stuff.

label says 10-2013. Pours a bit thin with some smaller bubbles. Nice toasty bright flavor and aroma, whiskey compliments excellent, very easy to drink, not too hot, bit thinner with some coarse fine carbonation, kind of tangy which is neat.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2015 Pours a really dark brown with a thin beige head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of bourbon, caramel and coffee. Taste is sweet but backed by some roastiness. Flavors of honey and coffee. Bourbon is more restrained than I thought it would be. Some spicy freshness. Carbonation is low, mouthfeel full. Alcohol is quite apparent but not disturbing. Great!

2012 bottle from Tommy, thanks man! Mind blowing aroma of, coffee, vanilla, oak and something else I cant quite place. Taste is a bit of cinnamon up front, thin mouthfeel, some bourbon oak notes, a bit of extra sweetness, nice bitter sweet aftertaste. A fantastic porter for a cold winter day.

Birth of tragedy 2013, bourbon barrel aged & in 500mL bottle. Brewed with honey & coffee. Delicious- complex but well balanced. The beer is sweet and the high alcohol content is noticable as a warmth on the palate, but does not detract from the drinkability. I'm sensing as much flavor from the aging in bourbon barrels as from the coffee. There are is also a dark fruit/ cherry character. Love it, so worth the drive through a snowstorm. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 vintage

Dark brown, flat appearing beer. Smells decadent: vanilla, oak, nougat, more vanilla, bits of graham, some cocoa, a hint of dark fruits. A really nice nose. Flavor follows suite - really fine dark chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, bits of minced licorice, some leather. The flavor is really nice also. Mouthfeel: this is where the beer falls apart. While full bodied with a silky feel, not even a swish through the teeth makes this bubbly, slightly wet. A real treat - with carbonation this would be hard to beat, honestly.
22oz bottle @the dmac Monmouth Park Horserace Gathering-tight lt brown-black. A-bourbon, roasty med malt, sweet dk fruit. T-bourbon, roasty med malt, sweet dk fruit-cherry, earthy/spice hops. 3.8

My first HF, courtesy of Mikem409. Nose of bourbon, sweet cherries. I cant get over the soft, smooth mouthfeel on this beer. Light carbonation. Taste of dark chocolate, cherry, caramel cream. Nice long lingering finish with slight bourbon notes. One of the better beers Ive had in a while. The water source they have is golden. Delicious.

Bottle from trade with MtGoat, cheers! This was the 11% 2011 version (and this is not from my long backlog, but from yesterday).
Black with a small beige head.
Aroma: sweet licorice, chocolate, bourbon, smooth roast.
Taste: licorice, creamy chocolate, bourbon, wood, light vinous, fudge, so very smooth and well balanced.
Medium bodied, very smooth.
Ah, this was so nice, actually didnt expect to like this as much as I did.

Shared by some cool dude at Sante. Low carb, molasses, huge port, chocolate syrup, spicy oak. Almost still on the palate, syrupy and delicious. Great drying woody finish after that rich raisin port blast.

Bottle tasting with Kaufmanised; pitch black pour with thin beige head, sweet aroma with a whiff of bourbon, sweet taste with a hint of caramel coffee a trace of bourbon some vanilla, with some spice, well balanced, excellent.

2012 bottle. Pours a brownish-black color with a medium foamy tan head that diminishes slowly. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla and coconut. Full-bodied with flavors of oaky vanilla, roasted malt and dark chocolate. The finish is roasty with a chocolate and coconut aftertaste. Good beer all around.

Sample from bottle. Dark black with a thin brown head. Splendid aroma with forceful maltiness and coffee. More roast and coffee in the taste with a vanilla accent. Mouthfeel is great but carbonation is sorely lacking. Would be approaching the outstanding category if it were not flat.

Bottle poured a black color with aromas of roast, chocolate, booze, light vanilla, and some light earth. Flavors are fudgey brownies dipped in bourbon, delicious in every way possible, thanks for sharing this one Glen.

Pour is black, with a brown hue, and a thing ring of off-white head.
Aroma has plenty of chocolate, with plenty of bourbon notes. Slight coffee, caramel, bourbon-soaked dark fruits, vanilla, slight roasted notes, slight wood, licorice, slight (very slight) green hoppy notes. There really is a lot going on in this on, and everything is mellowed by the smoothing bourbon sensation. 
The taste is quite sweet upfront, with bitter - and slight salty notes to it as well. I think this is quite well balanced and smooth, with a little heat to it. 
Medium and oily bodied, with a very flat carbonation. (I read that Batch 2 was a "flat batch"?) 
Thanks a lot to Ryan for giving me a shot at this.

Bottle - thanks Adam! Pours opaque black with a small dark brown creamy head that dissipates very slowly with great lacing. Flavor is bourbon, roasty coffee, anise, cocoa, very rich and thick. Medium sweet, medium bitter, just a touch of astringence. Full bodied and creamy.

Poured pitch black with no head. Nose was boozy, bourbon, bakers chocolate.

Taste was very boozy, sweetness from bourbon, espresso on back end and more booz. Reminded me of deliverance by lost abby

Bottle at Armins, courtesy of Armin. Thanks man!! Pour is deep viscous black with a very small brown head. Sweet malty, bourbon, coconut, raisins, figs, caramelly, brown sugar, and vanilla aroma. Taste is big chocolate, anise, coconut, light vanilla, oak, bourbon, leathery, and nutty with a touch of alcohol on the backend. Syrupy mouthfeel with very soft carbonation. Nice stuff.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks Kerry! Dark black pour with a thin white head, aroma brought notes of nice vanilla, coffee, earth, nice bourbon, slight oak, finishing fairly dessert like. Taste is a mix of big coffee, vanilla, nice chocolate, dark cocoa, nice bourbon, finishing fairly sweet, but nice bourbon, bitter, oak. Nice, not bad actually even with a slightly low carb level.

Bottle thanks to a trade! Pours black with a creamy dark brown head that dissipates to the edges quickly. Aroma has a good amount of musty coffee and musty dark grains with a bit of underlying bourbon. Flavor has sweet but musty dark grains with underlying bourbon and a decent amount of wet coffee backing. Mouth feel is a bit odd.

Bottle from deyholla, thanks! Pours ark mahogany... Pretty close to black. Nose is bourbon burn, rich malts and syrup molasses. Taste is pretty odd; very rich syrupy malts, bourbon and a good amount of coffee. Not bad but a bit cloying- no more than one sniffers worth please

Batch 2 (flat batch). pour us jet black with no head even with a vigorous pour. The nose is very nice, rich chocolate cake with a strong bourbon note and lightly scorched barrel. Taste has all the chocolate cake, dry chocolate through the finish, faint bourbon much less than the nose, virtually no carb with a burnt finish and a medium silky body.

50cl Bottle. Trade with Sean9689. Thanks. Pours black with a creamy lasting brown head and lacings. Nose is bourbon, vanilla, wood, dark fruit, mild spice and chocolate. Very smooth and silky soft mouthfeel with coffee roast, chocolate, wood and a bit of charcoal. Intense and complex. Sweet.  Every sip is incredible. Ohhh yes!

Bottle. Pours very dark with nice lacing around the rim. The aroma os a light sweet bourbon. The taste is very nice and smooth, the heat hits you in the middle and warms you. Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Thanks to foppa78 for sharing. Pours a black color with off white head.  Burnt, light roasty, bourbon flavors.  Very solid,

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2013 Bottle @ JetsonFest III, courtesy of foppa78. Mat is super nice! Pours a black appearance with a thin brown head. Spicy whiskey, light caramel, big anise, dark chocolate, smooth whiskey aroma. Marshmallow, rich dark chocolate, cocoa, light coffee, super smooth sweet whiskey, light toffee flavor. Cream chocolate goodness. Very nice stuff. http://i.imgur.com/fiyCweO.jpg
Bottle. Dark brown/black beer with a minimal offwhite head. Chocolate, tar, coffee and vanilla aroma. Coconut, chocolate, spicy, vanilla and a bit too much alcohol flavour.

Pours a pitch black with no head and no lacing. Aroma of bourbon, coffee, vanilla, roasted. Taste has lots of bourbon, coffee, vanilla, dark fruits, oak, roasted malts, brown suggar. Full body and minimal carb. Really good but that 12oz pour is killing me...

650ml bottle thanks to OmegaX
Appearance - Deep brown, frothy head
Aroma - Dirt and coffee inside a bourbon barrel
Taste - Chocolate, cherries, vanilla, oak, earthiness, smooth bourbon, bitter coffee finish

The aroma captured here is amazing, and the flavor matched quite nicely without being too boozy. These guys sure are talented.

Snifter pour. Aroma is big time barrel notes. Bourbon galore, with some dark chocolate, some earthiness, and dirty leaves. Flavor matches, with a nice vanilla and bourbon flavor on top of chocolate and dirt. Pretty interesting.

Bottle shared by someone during RBWG-JAX. Thanks! Black pour with a small tan head. The aroma shows nice barrel, touches of fudge, that goes well with the coffee, dark roasted malts, spice, and plenty of sweetness resembling brown sugar, molasses, etc. The flavor follows suit. Tasty stuff, but I dont see the crazy over HF like some do.

Bottle. 2012 vintage. Courtesy of futuraxz. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty bourbon and chocolate aroma. Roasted malty malty woody chocolate and bourbon flavor. Has a roasted malty woody chocolate and bourbon finish.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Near black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of coffee, molasses, booze, and wintergreen. Flavors are pretty much what youd expect, with elements of coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, bourbon, and a bit of wet stones on the finish. Heavy bodied in a good way. Solid overall.

2012 bottle...pours pitch black with a medium mocha head...looks thick.  Aroma has nice bourbon atop notes of toasted coconut, vanilla, and dsrk chocolate.  Flavor has sweet brown sugar, coffee, rich caramel, roasty dark chocolate, and wonderful bourbon.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy with a sweet coffee/warming bourbon finish.  Awesome dessert beer!

Bottle @ Stouts Tasting Pt II. The pours deep brown with a tiny head. The  nose is Swiss Miss hot cocoa. Ash. Roast malts. Hint of honeycomb and woody vanilla. The taste is quite sweet. Mashed banana and chocolate syrup. Slightly yeasty. Some toffee and coffee cake. Full body. Slightly oily. Overall, quite good. A step down after the dizzying heights of Jimmy.

Bottle consumed at THE stouts tasting part 2, thanks to Leighton. It pours very dark brown with pretty much no head. The nose is roasty, vanilla, toasted coconut, caramel and chocolate gateaux. The taste is pretty sweet, honey, rich-roasted coffee, toast, earth, light bitterness, burnt notes and chocolate gateaux. Full body, low carbonation and viscous, slightly cloying mouth-feel. Tasty, but a bit too sweet and chewy for me.

Bottle from the 1st (and I hope not the last) Rate Beer Awards dinner. Aroma is some smooth bourbon, chocolate, sweet licorice, and lightly roasted malts. Flavor was a much better, hit-you-in-the-face awesome, and the mouthfeel was reminiscent of RareR DOS (of course, bourbon rather than Rum). Knocks for being low on carbonation, but otherwise fantastic. Great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2013 Great barrel aged flavor from this winter porter. Coffee and honey, not a lot of carbonation, great beer! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of rich chocolate malt, bourbon, oak, vanilla bean ice cream, cinnamon sticks, rich decadent coffee and sweet milk chocolate. Medium body. Finishes with slight alcohol burn. Very smooth.

16.9 oz bottle, 2012.  Dark brown with a few oily tan bubbles.  Nose is oak, bourbon, espresso, prune and hay.  Thick and creamy with a soothing buzz.  After my first sip i thought this was way overdone.  Certainly a huge beer but not overwhelming.  Chocolate syrup, rich coffee, vanilla oak and honey.  Just when you almost forget about it, the bourbon comes out with some coffee bean in the finish.  The honey really sings here.  I cant think of a better porter.

From Bottle at RBWG.  Pours dark brown, some mahogany hues, small yellow tan head.  Nose shows lots of spice, cocoa, light coffeee upfront, nice roast and light barrel.  Flavor is similar, lots of complexity and well balanced for such a big beer with a lot going on.  Very nice, I wish I could have spent more than 5 mins with it.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2013 Bottle shared at Bruces, London during The Stouts Tasting, Pt. II - youre welcome, bros! And thanks to Momma Laura for swinging by Greenboro to grab this. Pours clearish, oily black with a small, tan foam head. Sweet dark malts in the nose, sugary chocolate, burnt wood, robust coffee. Big sweet flavor, ripe dark fruits, rich chocolate cake, brown sugar, mellow earthy bitterness. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly warming finish, lots of sugary dark malts, some coffee, more cake, syrupy chocolate, light earthy bitterness. One of the sweeter beers of the night, but I think its delicious and has enough depth to warrant the sweetness. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2013 Bottle, poured into a Heretic snifter. Pours pitch black, silky and luscious. No head what-so-ever, looks like dark coffee, or still coffee after left out for a few days. Sad sight to see. Smell is intense with mocha, vanilla, fudge, sweet bourbon, honey, coffee. Pretty unreal. The taste is smooth. Smooth smooth smooth. With a beautiful amount of sweet bourbon to tie into the honey, and vanilla like latte. Lingering bits of milk chocolate, brownies or fudge. A very impressive taste, but overall the mouth feel is completely shattered by the lack of carbonation. This could have been the best beer I ever had, but instead its a simply stunning beer that goes down way too easy. Lacks the challenging mouth feel that makes a great beer the best beer. Nevertheless still a great one to try!

Bottle shared at the RBWG grand tasting 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small tan head, light lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts and spices 
Taste: Roasted malts, vanilla, spices and coffee  
Ok

On tap at 2012 Harvest Festival.

Pours an opaque, still and ominous motor oil black with a trace mocha head that quickly dissipates.   Aroma has a strong bourbon presence, blending with chocolate, molasses, vanilla, roast coffee, raisin, plum and cocoa (basically everything wonderful).  Syrupy, oily thick body with gentle carbonation, little alcohol presence or cloying sweetness. Flavor of a robust porter, roast and chocolate malt, layered with molasses, burnt sugar, vanilla, bourbon.  Ive had good to great experiences with this (in bottle and draft) and this was one of the  great ones.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 500ml bottle (2012) in a snifter.  Pours black with a lacy, tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, coffee, honey, roasted malts, and light hops.  Flavor the same, with a lot of bourbon and malts.  Smooth to thicker texture.  A great beer, slightly reminiscent of the Struise Black Damnation beers.
Edit: 2013 bottle in a snifter.  Black.  A great blend of bourbon, coffee, roasted malts.  Incredible.
Black pour with tan head. Aroma is coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is sweet chocolate and coffee with a roasted malt bitter. Smooth with good carbonation. A nice beer.

On tap at Hill Harvest Festival 12, not sure which vintage this is. pours black with soapy tan head. aroma has port, cocoa, and vanilla. flavors with a rich coconut and vanilla thing, hazelnut chocolate, really tasty.

4th February 2012Opaque black beer, short lived tan head. Smooth and almost silky palate. Smooth dark malt. Coffee, mild spice. Slightly tangy and semi sweet bourbon. The famous Hill Farmstead balance - nothing dominates. Finishes semi dry with the mild spice a little more noticeable. Light on its toes and pretty drinkable. Lacks a wow factor and thus not in the highest echelons.

2012 bottle thanks to Tyler! Pours dark brown, no head and nearly no bubbles or carbonation.
Nose is bourbon, lightly roasted malt and oak--tons of boozy vanilla.
Medium to full mouth feel.
Taste is  brown sugar, molasses, dry whiskey, bit of dark chocolate. Finishes with whiskey soaked oak. Great barrel aged porter with lots of barrel character. I enjoyed this much more than the 2011 vintage despite less carbonation because of the distinct bourbon notes, but best to drink fresh if you enjoy it like I do.

Bottle generously shared by Tim/Bill once they saw I brought the base beer for this. It was nice trying them back to back to note the differences. Silky black color with thin beige head. Aromas and taste are delicious with roasted coffee bean, bitterseet choc bar, cinnamon, and loads on chocolate chip cookie dough as it warmed! Mostly in the aroma, other notes of graham, bourbon, Pap, and light citrus. I liked twilight better but this one was seriously rich meh.

500 ml bottle shared by cosmicevan. Served in a HF wine glass.

A: Pours an opaque deep brown color with some clearer edges. A thin tan head forms on the pour and recedes quickly to a thin ring. A few splotches of lace are left down the glass.

S: Smooth bourbon up front with a ton of fudge. Heavily roasted malts with a light chocolate sweetness. Besides the smoothness and lightness of the bourbon the barrel isnt all that noticeable. 

T: The taste just took on a complexity that wasnt found in the nose. The smoothness of the bourbon carried over and blended wonderfully with some ground coffee beans and espresso notes. The bourbon took a sweeter turn mid palate and balanced the heavy roasted malt body. A little oak barrel shows up and blend nicely with a rich and lush chocolate on the finish.

M: Low carbonation here with a medium to light body. For hour luscious the taste was I would have liked a little more body to this.

O: Absolutely delicious. I like Twilight of the Idols, but I like this even more. If they would beef up the gravity a bit I bet this would be able to hold onto the barrel a little better and get a better mouthfeel. Still, Im just nitpicking here. A great beer.

Serving type: bottle

2011 bottle. The scent is of bourbon, roasted coffee beans, and slight vanilla. I taste coffee, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and roasted malts. It leaves a malt and a weak bourbon aftertaste that fades over time. Overall this is a nice smooth brew.

Bottle served at about 50 degrees poured into HF glassware. Pours a jet black with very little head. Scents are bourbon, chocolate, molasses. Taste follows heavy molasses Bourbon and a nice chocolate hint in there. This is the second bottle I had and temperature really plays a part in the flavors. I really enjoyed this... Mr. Hill does it again.

(500ml bottle) clear deep brown, deep tan head. Nose of bourbon, vanilla, graham cracker, chocolate, barrel, light alcohol. Taste of bourbon, chocolate, cream, vanilla, graham cracker, rich, super complex. Amazing.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2014 2013 brings proper carb and exceptional depth of flavors. Beautiful beer too: sticky brown lace & head overstay their welcome. Honey kiss midway through balances the bourbon presence. Fuck, thats good. 

2012. Dry porter yeast amidst bourbon and roasty malts in the nose. Palate sees honey, chocolate, more roast, mild bourbon barrels, vanilla. Layers of flavor fold into each other masterfully. Big, viscous body is perfectly suited for a brew this complex. Nearly flat carb level is the only disappointment. A superb imperial porter nonetheless.

500ml bottle, 2012 vintage, courtesy of Dan and Tim.  Thanks!  Pours a deep, dark brown color with no head, no bubbles.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate, some vanilla. Heavy on the palate with zero carbonation.  None.  Flat.  Flavor is sweet, decadant, chocolate, coffee, light bourbon, vanilla, coconut, smooth roasty malt, with a big, chocolatey finish.  For me, the flavor is amazing, but the lack of carbonation is a big disappointment.  Still a great beer, but it would probably be top 5 with bubbles.

Pours black as night of out the bottle with no head.  Split this bottle up between three of us.  Heavy raisin on the nose.  The body hits me with lovely bourbon.  I find myself missing the vanilla from Twilight.  This is great sipping beer for desert though.

Brought back from the north by a friend, thanks for the hookup Matt.
Pours a solid black color with about forty bubbles eventually making their way to the surface. Yup this one is flat. Smells of chocolate brownie batter, coconut, light bourbon, coffee, a bit of oak tannin and some sugary sweetness to tie this all together. The flavor is sweet and chocolatey with a bit of coconut, caramel, roast, warming alcohol, tannin, and earthy hop to provide some balance. This tastes like an alcoholic mounds bar really. Medium to thick body with a non existent level of carbonation and a sweet syrupy sugary mouthfeel. This honestly smells wonderful, tastes good, but the lack of bubbles messes with the mouthfeel a bit leaving a syrupy feel to it. Id love to try this with bubbles.
Very bourbonny porrer. Reminiscent of wi brews thinner mouthfeel and bourbon domi.ates. sweet caramel.

Bottle (50 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Black with no head. Sygary and slightly alcoholic with pungent bourbon vanilla and coconut character. Medium to full bodied, low carbonation. Semi sweet, low to medium bitterness, some wood tannins.

Bottle received in trade. Thank you Glouglouburp! Pours Black with a thin mocha head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and spicy with toasted malts, ginger, vanilla fudge, cinnamon, bourbon, dark roast coffee, roasted coconut, cloves, dark piney honey, black pepper and alcohol. Taste is sweet and slightly malty with roasted malts, coconut, bourbon, cinnamon, cloves, vanilla fudge, dark roast coffee, dark honey, oatmeal cookies, slightly dry grass and hints of sheet metal. Mouthfeel is smooth, round, slightly boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, dark honey, cinnamon, coconut, vanilla and bourbon. Bit unbalanced.

(Bottle) Pours black with small brown head. The aroma holds deep roast (coffee, wet asphalt, dark chocolate and a touch of dark caramel), Spices (maybe cinnamon, vanilla and clove), Bourbon (booze, wood, fudge, touch of coconut and vanilla) and a balanced hop profile. The flavor is light sweet, near heavily bitter and tiny acidic with notes of boozy bourbon, spices, deep coffee roast and bitter hops. The mouthfeel is numbing, light syrupy and oily with light carbonation. Fat malty, spicy, light dark fruity and boozy finish. Medium to full bodied.

Bottle rlgks tasting. Pours black oily with a small ring of brown bubbles. Aroma is slightly boozy bourbon vanilla dill sweet roasted malty caramel. Flavor is sweet velvety bourbon barrel character vinous slight roasted touch with some coffee and chocolate prunes bitter and some fruityness. Finishes bitter vanilla and a bit sweet.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Pitch black beer with a small brownish head. Spicy bourbon aroma, vanilla, rather roasted, chilli, chocolate, cocoa, hay, peat, salty, figs, coffee beans, slightly boozy, dades, raisins, cinnamon, pepper, honey, caramel notes, some grass. Coffee flavor, bourbon, cinnamon, hay, cocoa powder, licorice, vanilla, salty, chilli notes, chocolate. Spicy peat finish with coffee, hay, spices, dark chocolate and vanilla notes.

Sampled at USSkovde
Black with a bubbly, beige head. 
Vinous and sourish aroma. Roasted, milky chocolate, coffee, cinnamon and bourbon. 
Wood, bourbon, coffee and milky chocolate in the flavour. 
Sweet, brown sugar, vanilla and coconut. A bit protruding alcohol. And too much spicys.
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Smells vanilla, candy and roasted malt. Tastes vanilla, chili, creamy and chocolate. Sadly abit to much alcohol.

Bottle sent to me by jedwards a while back. Beautifully paired with the movie "Fargo". This is the perfect winter/holiday beer. Black with reddish tinge, and a small light brown head, quickly dissipating. Aroma is very rich - lush chocolate and brownie mixes with a delicately balanced bourbon presence. Vanilla bean and cinnamon in the background. Complex dark fruit notes - much like caramel soaked dried figs as well as vanilla fudge. No unpleasant burnt notes or anything - I couldn't really imagine that this aroma could be improved. The taste showcases an amazingly complex malt bill - chocolate, dark caramel, dark fruit, some roasted bitterness. Bourbon provides huge vanilla presence, cinnamon is somewhere in the mix, too. A lovely coffee note in the finish, very fruity and only slightly bitter, accentuated by a restrained hoppiness. This is the ultimate winter beer to enjoy on this evening of one of the first really cold days. It's sweet without being cloying, bourbonesque without being alcoholic. No problem to drink a whole bottle of this.

It is burstingly restrained, it is complex in a simple way. Its nature does not demand extravagancy. Everything this beer does, it does near perfectly.

on tap at hill farmstead harvest festival. murky black, some floaters, without a head. complex aroma: roasted beans, chocolate, coffee, spices, coconut, bourbon, burnt nuts, resin and pine. slightly boozy. soft carbonation, full body - syrupy, decent resinous coffee finish, a tad sweet though. but great juice!

On tap at HF Harvest Fest. Black pour with a few scarce brown bubbles. Aroma is very bourbon forward, really clean, spicy aroma with lots of anise and molasses. Taste is sweet, maybe a tad overly so - could have used a bit more bitterness. Palate was a tad flat which did nothing to help the impression of sweetness. Good barrel use however, the bourbon was perfectly incorporated.

On tap at HF.
Pour black with almost no head. Aroma is of malt, vanilla, bourbon, sweetness. Taste is of vanilla, wine, bourbon, chocolate, malt, alcohol. Full bodied. Overall: An outstanding beer. The bourbon really gives a wonderfull touch to that brew.

On tap at Hill Farmstead Harvest Festival. Thanks to Czar for sharing this one! Black with almost no head. Aroma of bourbon (but not overwhelming), roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate and spices. Taste is about the same. As expected, not much carbonation in this one. This is a perfect example of what can be done with bourbon barrel aging. Superb complexity and balance. Another amazing beer by Hill Farmstead!

On draft at HFS Harvest Fest... poured a deep burnt umber leaning toward black with no visible head. On the nose this beer was focused and balanced... rich chocolate, vanilla bean, bourbon and delicate touches of spent coffee grounds and smokey tar. On the palate this stuff is delicious and  elegant... ripe sweet cocoa flavors; cocoa puffs, vanilla and a hint of licorice to brighten up the finish and cut through the full viscosity of this mouth coating splendid nectar... first HFS stout and I was very impressed !

Poured by Shaun Hill at the 2012 HFS Harvest Fest into an HFS Taster Wine Glass. Served a bit cold around 50 Degrees but we allowed it to warm up before enjoying. Thanks Shaun for sharing this with everyone!

A - Deep dark brown to black. Amber hues against the light. Looks like milk chocolate. No head, almost no carbonation. Decent alcohol legs for an 11% beer with no lacing (probably due to age?)

S - Very boozy with a lot of bourbon & vanilla. Charred oak, some smoked malts. Espresso beans and dark chocolate. 

T - Front Taste: Coffee, milk chocolate. Middle: Rum and Bourbon with a hint of vanilla. Finish: Charred oak and cough syrup. 

M - No carbonation at all. Very flat, viscous and oily. Very heavy body. It really coats everything.

O -

Was served it @ Harvest. Ran out very quickly.  Pours a syrupy charcoal deep dark brown with a quickly diminishing trim khaki-esque head. Smells straightaway of Swiss Miss, nutmeg, whiskey, prunes, cinnamon and chocolate malt. Tastes of cocoa powder/Swiss Miss hot chocolate packets, raisins, Dutched chocolate, matured oak, spices and currant syrup. Was quite treacly on the palate. Overall enjoyable.

Draft at HFS harvest festival. Deep brown with ruby highlights. Head is tiny beige bubbles. Nose and taste is deeply complex. Bourbon up front, followed by rich coffee beans covered in caramel. Charred malt with a high viscosity that you can actually see sticking to the side of the glass. The coffee and bourbon show up again in the finish however, a sweet finish. ABV does not exist anywhere in this brew. Absolutely wonderful. Shaun Hill makes yet another masterpiece. Well done sir!

Bottle 500ml.[ Courtesy of fiulijn ]. Clear dark black brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted ,spicy, chocolate, wood, alcohol. Flavour is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dark chocolate, english licorice - dark dreid fruit, wood. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. [20120617]

Sampled at EBF. For a porter this holds a lot of qualities that are true to BA stout standards. Very dark color and big aroma of bourbon,chocolate and coffee. Full of flavor and character, would love to try again.

Huge thanks to Allen for opening this one.  Pours a porter brown with a tan head.  Nose is roasted malts, dark fruit, plum, licorice, pepper, wood, slight bourbon,  and chocolate.  Flavor is similar with chocolate, spice, dark fruit, plum, dark chocolate, and some light wood and and almost no bourbon.  The spirits and barrel character is a seamless blend.  Outstanding beer.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2016 2016-12-18, hunted by Sergey, bottled 9.21.16, 9-5-10-4-19=47The aroma shows spicy notes, a bit of alcohol. Most smooth beer, sweet dark chocolate, chili pepper kick, alcohol warmth, coffee, and vanilla beans in the final.Wonderful, one of the best Imperial Porters, and its amazing that its good batch after batch.2012-06-17, courtesy of Yespr, 9-4-9-4-18=44Pitch black color, oily, with small brown head. The aroma is spicy (ancho chilies), with roasted malt, chocolate, wood, nice coffee and some vanilla. Good body, round mouthfeel; strong flavor of dark chocolate, very rich, with moderate but pleasing sweetness, tar and tobacco, vanilla, very light liquorice, some wood; correct bitterness; the final has a light spicy vein too; there is some alcohol warmth, but the alcohol is very well hidden.Excellent.
Bottle thanks Ernesto. Pours black no head. Aroma of coffee and bourbon. Taste was lots of coffee and slight sweet vanilla. No carbonation

19/V/2012 - 500ml bottle @ De Hopduvel - BB: n/a (2012-522) Thanks to BoBoChamp for sharing the beer!
Clear dark brown beer, no head. Aroma: sweet, sugary, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol, dried fruits, liquorish, brown sugar. MF: no carbon, full body. Taste: dark chocolate, some mocha, caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, little bitter, somewhat fruity. Aftertaste: lots of vanilla, bourbon, dark caramel, some liquorish, syrup, raisins, mocha, touch of burned toast.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2013 Arôme spectaculaire de cannelle, chocolat, café avec une barricade de bourbon. Son corps est pratiquement lacté. Lalcool est très présente en arôme comme en bouche et ya une sorte de surcharge des saveurs, très sucré.

50cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, with honey, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex sweet Porter, roasted/sweet and slightly alcoholic/spicy, yet not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good Winter brew, yet very expensive!

From notes.  Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a snifter.

Birth of Tragedy pours a mahogany, nearly black color with a small tan mocha cap.  

Lots of espresso, somewhat bitter and a bit creamy, dark bitter chocolate, sweet milk chocolate, roasted malt, and a bit of spicy hops in the nose.  

The flavor is full of a ton of espresso, a bit of cream, dark, bitter chocolate, deeply roasted malt, and a bit of spice toward the finish.  There is a sweetness to some of chocolate notes, but overall it is fairly bitter.  There is not very much bourbon character coming through.

The mouthfeel is fairly full, there is a creamy carbonation.  It is a bit acrid in its bitterness, with a dryness toward the end.  Even without the bourbon flavor coming through, it feels like the dryness from the oak barrel came through fairly strongly.

 It was fairly nice, but I really noticed the acrid nature of it, which detracted from the experience.

A very good porter.  Fortunately the bourbon is mild and attenuated rather than overpowering. The aroma has coffee and vanilla with oak, but not much bourbon in the aroma, which I was expected. Flavor has more coffee and roasted grain, and light bourbon.  A thick, rich porter with a smooth palate.

500ml bottle, thanks ben.  Pours a very still, slightly watery looking black.  Sweet bourbon barrel notes with cinnamon, bit or raisins, light chocolate and coffee, vanilla.  The faintest of carbonation present, really I would call it still, with the body being on the thin side.  Bourbon, prunes, cinnamon, bitter coco notes, subtle vanilla.  Intoxicating nose and really reminds me in some ways of a hair of the dog beer, but being a bit thinner in the nose and body.

Big bourbon nose patent dark malt dark fruit a little peppery and spicey. Coffee.  Nice aroma.  Wood alcohol. Inky Black pour thin tan head. Woody bourbpny dark malt dark fruit. Brown sugar. Big boozy. Some  coffee comes through. Not very carbonated. Boozy spicy bourbpny. Big and sweet.

Thanks for the pour, Ryan!  Pours out a deep, dark brown with a touch of head - fairly low carbed.  Aroma is impressive - tons of coffee, sweet brown surgar, a touch of bourbon and booze, and a layer of chocolate.  Very impressive, and the best part of the beer.  Taste follows where the nose leaves off.  Rich coffee, more bourbon than the nose indicates, caramel/honey sweetness.  Impressive.  A touch thin and undercarbed.  Excellent beer, but I cant help wishing it was a bit thicker and with more carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 Brought this to our Hill Farmstead tasting. Looks similar to Damon only with a little but more head. Head still has some soapiness to it.  Nose is packed full of coffee, honey, and chocolate, there is also some slight booziness, but not much barrel character. Flavor starts with a little booziness, then moves to rich chocolate, coffee, caramel, oak, and honey. Mouthfeel is on the lighter side again. Carbonation is lower and it has a medium finish. Very good BA porter. I wish the barrel character would show up a little more, but its still a nice beer.
