Bottle, courtesy of GT2 - thank you sir! Pour is ink black, tan head, some retention/lace. Aroma of coconut, vanilla, barrel, dark chocolate, coffee, cream. Taste is rich chocolate, coconut, vanilla, bourbon, some booze. Palate is full bodied, oily, slick, soft carbonation, warming finish.

500ml bottle.  Dark brown in color with a small light tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, and cinnamon as well as a hint of whiskey barrels on the aroma.  Nice complex flavor marred only slightly by an anise/spice note thats a bit too strong.  Other than that, nicely spicy with rich chocolate, coffee, and whiskey.  Smooth mouthfeel with medium-full body and lower carbonation.  Not the best Ive had from Hill Farmstead but still really good.

Translucent sepia, thinnest white ring, wispy, oily top. Lightly burnt cake, juniper, chocolate cake and light pine resin. Balanced and nuanced. Silky nuanced body shows delicate anise, milk chocolate,  more dry cake through finish, smoke emerging in end. Thinner, more integrated than Damon but less complex (hops?)
This bottle was rather flat, not sure if thats common for this beer. Still, the beer is very nice,  soft chewy chocolate,  light brown sugar,  just a touch of dark fruit.  Rather quick finish. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a flat trace of tan head; short retention and no lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, licorice, dark fruit, bourbon, earthy notes, and some oak.  Flavor is malt dominate with some supporting dark fruit esters; bourbon and vanilla undertones throughout. Medium/full body, low carbonation, and medium warmth.

Bottle shared by craftycarl. Pours opaque with a small, fizzy light tan head, short retention with spare lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, roast and nutty malt, dark fruity esters, licorice and booze.  Flavor is malt dominant, dark fruity esters, chocolate, oak and booze with a sweet finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

500ml bottle.  The pour yields a dark and dense, inky-looking mahogany body with a very short head of bubbly mocha froth.  Lacing is limited to a few micro-spots that escape the viscous sheeting that briefly stains the glass.  Once warm, the nose reveals a rich malt base of dark chocolate, caramel, stewed plums and rummy raisins.  It smells very fruit forward, with figs and dates also joining the fold.  Faded coffee lends just a bit of earthiness, while distant juniper-like spicing and perhaps a wisp of spruce tend to brighten things up a bit.  Its boozy, with notes of vanilla laden bourbon and maybe some mead-like fermented honey qualities.  The flavor is pulled together well, loaded with bittersweet dark chocolate, muddled dark fruits, and perhaps some earthen tobacco.  Coffee asserts itself a good deal more than the nose lets on, working along the green hop elements to add a rustic bitterness.  Burnt honey again creeps in on the back end, as does warming, heavily-wooded bourbon.  As expected, the palate is dense and boozy, lacking a bit in carbonation and missing out on some liveliness.  The finish is long, biting, and bittersweet.  Overall, its a solid brew, but it comes across overly syrupy and hot for my tastes.  Definitely a slow sipper to be split between a few folks.  Not Hill Farmsteads best effort.

Opaque black with a thin tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, whiskey, and alcohol. Taste of roasted malts, some smoke, vanilla, dark fruits, somewhat brandy-ish, with whiskey and some booze in the finish.

Thanks ramnuts

Appearance- Black body with a tan head. Slight lacing. 

Smell- Vanilla is first rounded out by dark chocolate 

Taste- The Alcohol is a big part. It move right up to your sinuses. Dark chocolate, roasted malts, and bits of vanilla.  

Mouthfeel- Nice and thick. Just the way I like it.  

Overall - Good beer. I would drink this more often if it was readily available to me, alas it is not.

Bottle shared by Peter at STL RB gathering, thanks man!! Usually at the long drawn out beer tastings, the beers that get opened towards the end tend to lose their edge and are less memorable for me. Wow did this one change my mind about that.  Pour is deep, dark , cloudy brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma and flavor are loaded with deep roasty malt, faint raisins, faint earthy spice, a touch of hay and a smooth rounded coffee note. This beer is so smooth and so well balanced. Again, I do love this brewery. Not sure if its their yeast, their style, or what. But all of their beers have an extra layer of depth that adds an indescribable earthy, rounded, spice note that I cannot get enough of.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 Tootsie Roll brown pour, slightly translucent at the edges, with barely a whisper of a head.  Chocolate, coffee, prune, barrel, and booze in the nose.  Taste adds a little vanilla.  Palate is slick and oily, but surprisingly thin with a hot/boozy finish.  11% is both too high and too noticeable in this beer for my personal taste.   These bigger Hill Farmstead beers just arent working for me.  The smaller but robust and wholesome Everett just destroys both Twilight of the Idols and this bigger sibling in my opinion.

500 ml bottle sent by lushawn- thanks again, Shawn! Pours an opaque dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, honey, toasted oak, mixed spices, bourbony booze, and molasses. Flavor of roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, honey, caramel, spices that are milder than in the aroma, and dark fruits, like raisins, plums, and figs. Full-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a chewy mouthfeel. So rich and complex and tasty. Loved this.

Sampled at the StL RB gathering.  It poured a black color with a small off-white head. The aroma was of toasted vanilla, bourbon, roasted malts, chocolate and spices. The taste was tons of bourbon and barrel character.  A very good Winter Porter.

Tasted from large bottle at 2nd STL Ratebeer Gathering, thanks phaleslu for another delicious rarity! Poured an opaque, dark brown color with only a thin layer of bubbles but some lace. Aromas of roasted barley, mild malt, toast, honey, caramelized brown sugar, fruity hops and yeast esters. Tons of flavor: strong coffee, vanilla, malt sweetness, dark chocolate, raisins, plums, sour cherries. Bring to mind every sweet thing you ever tasted, then caramilze it and ferment it. Lighter body than an Imperial Stout, which is better in my opinion. Smooth, warm, well-concealed alcohol. Phenomenal.

500mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany!), pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma of vanilla beans, honey, coffee, brandy-like liqueur, light wood, and some subtle molasses - exquisite on the nose. Flavour is nearly exactly the same, with perhaps a higher proportion of brandy / liqueur notes dominating. I dont get the bourbon barrels at all, just the liqueur, assuming this is how that flavour was created. Very complex, full-bodied, but somehow extremely easy to drink as well. Very enjoyable, though I would say just short of a masterpiece beer.

In short: A not-too-bourbonny BA coffee stout with a soft spiciness.  Excellent.
How: Super-fresh tap at the brewery + bottle age 2 months
The look: Black body topped by a small tan head
In long: Nose is only moderately bourbonny over a rich dark maltiness with notes of vanilla and coffee beans.  Taste is relatively smooth for a 11% BA big beer, round and smooth full body, coffee, vanilla beans, cookies, black chocolate, dark caramel, delicate spiciness, very light vinous notes.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden.  Basically this beer offers the standard elements you expect from a bourbon barrel aged coffee stout, but it doesnt overdo the barrel aspect, adds a soft candy spiciness, and more importantly the beer is relatively easy to drink.  I cant say I agree with the ratings that are making this beer almost the best Hill Farmstead beer, to me this is an average Hill Farmstead offering, which means it is only excellent.  But this is ratebeer and this is a big barrel aged black beer, so Anyway, it is not easy to get up very early on a Saturday morning, drive a long distance to a beer release and stand in line outside in the cold just to get a rare beer, but bragging about it to strangers on the internet makes it all worthwhile.

Pours dark thick oil in color with virtually no head, some light dark caramel bubbles on top. The aroma is sweet notes of the bourbon barrels with no alcohol at all. The flavor has nice sweet and light boozy bourbon notes that are very smooth on the palate. The body is medium thickness with almost no carbonation at all, but that isnt a bad thing by any means. Thanks again Shaun!

Sampled at STL RB Gathering - Pours dark brown with a ring of a tan head.  The aroma is roasty with spiciness, coffee and light cocoa - very clean aroma that has a sort of freshness to it.  Mediium smooth bodey with minor carbonation.  The flavor starts with cocoa, richness, coffee and spices.  The finish has nice roast and roasty coffee.  Really nicely done.

Sample at Night of the Barrels (EBF) and a pre-sample at Hill Farmstead from Shaun. Black with a dark biege head that stay in the glass all the way through. You get roasted malts but they seem fresher, bourbon aging is done very well - does not overwhelm but the vanilla, oak and alcohol enhance the porter - you also get some spice, coffee, chocolate, some brown sugar as well. Full body, moderate carbonation, nice roasted malt and bourbon flavour, becomes drier, somewhat sweet and very tasty.

500ml bottle with huge thanks to Ernesto987 for hooking me up with this rarity. pours a deep, dusky black with rich, dark ruby highlights around the edges that is topped by a sliver of beige foam that leaves oily legs on the edges of the glass. aroma is fantastic, truly a unique one for me, with rich notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, and cardamon complimented by sweet brown sugar, molasses,and toasted oak backed by subtle hints of vanilla, spiced bourbon, graham crackers, and fresh espresso. as it warms, im picking up notes of raw maple syrup, Myers rum, and raisin bread. flavor is absolutely wonderful as well with a rich blend of sweet, turbinado sugar, molasses, and vanilla with spice notes of cinnamon and nutmeg backed by roasted espresso, dark cocoa, and honey-dipped dark fruits with elegantly integrated barrel notes of toasted coconut, charred oak, and distinctly smooth notes of Blantons bourbon. the finish brings forth light roast, cocoa, pralines, and a touch of smoke. palate is smooth, rich, and full bodied with light carbonation but still leaves me longing for another swig. overall, an absolute masterful example of barrel aging and one hell of an mperial porter.

Pouring at the Night of the Barrels on the Friday night of EBF 2012.  Pours a deep viscous black.  Big bourbon on the nose, sweet malt, roast, chocolate, and a touch of char.  Long coffee and bourbon, wood with warm vanilla.  Chocolate and bourbon, wood and sweet roast.  Delicious.

Bottle courtesy of aapp. Served in a Hill Farmstead long-stem tulip.

Pours black with a good tan-mocha head and nice retention. Lacing on the glass. The nose brings forward very smooth bourbon with a bit of roast and chocolate. Some coffee there as well. Flavor integrates bourbon and chocolate quite well. Nicely done, but nothing to really bring it over the top. Mouthfeel is ultra smooth without any trace of alcohol. Fantastic barrel usage, but lacking the final oomph.

Bottle thanks to GRG1313. Really impressed by this one. Pours with a near black body and a small tan head that fades. Aromas are of dark fruits, molasses, demerara, evergreens, bourbon, fruit rollups and coffee. Delicious. Flavors are thick, spicy and vinous, dark fruits, tannin, and vanillin. A bit chalky. Thick, viscous, low bubbles and mouthcoating. Lightly warming. Excellent!

Sample at Central Waters anniversary party.  Deep brown/black.  Absolutely amazing nose of light bourbon and roasted malt, cocoa powder, molasses, brown sugar, and vanilla.  Flavor is sticky treat of molasses, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, bourbon, and roasted malt.  All flavors soft and well blended.  Residual roast/coffee, sticky malts, and faint bourbon.  Amazing.

Woah. Buddy brought this one over. Dark brown pour, with a small off-white almost tan head. Aroma was bourbon notes - wood, vanilla, light chocolate notes. Woah - the flavor. Was. Literally. Amazing.Flavors were woody, bourbon, vanilla, roasted notes. Alcohol is entirely hidden - jeez, 11%. Insane.

500ml thanks to MtGoat.
Appearance : Black with medium head.

Aroma : Big rich roasted malt. Licorice. Sweet. 

Taste : Chocolate with roasted malt, light coffee. Rather spicy with big rich vanilla on the finish.

Palate : Velvety and soft palate. Great palatable finish.

Overall : Very nice. Awesome vanilla that lingers all along the very long and persistent finish along the dark chocolate and light coffee. A great example of a well done bourbon ageing. Great nose and taste but the finish is what made the biggest impression on me. Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2015 My Bottom Line :  
Coffee beans, biscuity cereals and dark chocolate ground this Barrel-Aged Imperial Coffee Porters relatively subtle bourbon vanilla, as spicy nuances construct an even more tantalizing finish.

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A slice of foam floats atop the darkness.
-The spiciness could be mistaken for clove-like phenolics; its that well integrated to the rest of the flavor profile. 
-Light alcohol burn reminds you this is a powerful brew while never bothering the flavor profile. 
-The mouthfeel is once again rich and amazingly soft.
-Cinnamon sticks are imagined in the finish, alongside the chocolate and coffee lengths.

Bottles.

Pours pretty much black in color with a very small khaki head.  Intense roasted malt and bourbon aromas.  Lots of vanilla notes to it.  Theres a bit of the honey coming through as well as the coffee.  I dont get much spice, though.  A nice bit of chocolate in the back ground.  The flavor is a touch boozy at first, but otherwise quite nice.  Excellent vanilla and bourbon notes with some roast, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Really smooth and well done.  Medium to full bodied with a low, smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle thanks to OteyJ.  01/1/2012.  Pours black with thin tan head, decent retention, fading to an espresso crema type haze, and great lacing.  Ridiculous aroma, decadent chocolate, cacao beans, ground espresso, blending seamlessly with caramel, vanilla, bourbon.  Taste features heavy vanilla, chocolate coffee liqueur, bitter roast, bourbon finish, hot but smooth.  Medium thin in the mouth yet silky, mouthwatering.  Awesome offering from Hill Farmstead.

Bottle shared by Koopa

A: Dark black with a minimal brownish head. A few stray stands of lacing.

S: Bourbon, caramel, molasses, honey sweetness.

T: Like the nose there is a healthy dose of bourbon and sweet malts. Definitely some caramel, dark fruits, and a little smokey/roasty malts.

M: Medium-full bodied. Light carbonation. A tad too much residual sweetness in the finish.

O: An interesting effort, but a bit too ambitious.

Bottle...  Poured a dark as night black with a brownish head.  Incredibly sweet with succulent barrel and whiskey characters.  Some acidity from maybe the coffee that helped thin out the body.  Cocoa, dark spices and malt sweetness.  Caramel/toffee toasted sweetness, dense cake.  Fortified vanilla extract intensity, low bitterness and incredibly smooth on the palate.

Pour from the bottle thanks to Robert in NH for scoring this fine offering. Dark black in appearance. Aromas of malt goodness and sweet honey. Full rich body and smooth in your mouth. Coffee, molasses, natural honey, roasted toasted malt, anise, chocolate, vanilla. This beer is definitely complex and interesting not to mention very tasty.  The finish brings out some mild bitter hops and balanced dryness. The bourbon oakiness is not overpowering or off the top. Alcohol heat subdued. Great beer.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours black with a bubbly ring of tan head. Nose is coffee grounds, cigarettes, whiskey, and sharp alcohol--actually too sharp for my tastes. KBS-lite. Dry and astringent, with some roasty malt there as well. (But, as it warms, it get much better. Sweeter and less astringent.) Full-flavored smell, but just too harsh for me. Tastes a bit better--lots of vanilla, milk chocolate, coffee, and toffee. The boozy warmth works well on the finish--its almost a Irish coffee sort of flavor. Dark chocolate, coffee, and vanilla on the finish. Very nice. Pretty viscous, but medium-bodied. Wasnt blown on my ass with my first Hill Farmstead beer, but this was pretty damn good.

Bottle muled by oteyj, thanks very much!  Murky dark maroon color, tiny brown head had to be coaxed.  Aroma of whiskey, vanilla, chocolate syrup.  Taste is whiskey, coffee, vanilla.  Slightly too much whiskey, I think, but not bad. Cant tell it apart from an imperial stout.

Thanks Lee .. . Pours as dark as the inside of a well diggers ass .. . light foam .. . rich tar, dark roast, dark vanilla, coffee grounds, and nighttime .. . pretty damn nice .. . . . When I was a kid my favorite relative was Uncle Caveman. After school wed all go play in his cave, and every once in a while he would eat one of us. It wasnt until later that I found out that Uncle Caveman was a bear.

500ml bottle again thanks to Wallace... Pours a deep oily stouty black hue with burnt reddish edges and a wispy tan head... Aroma has a bunch of complexity with an inky iodine nature to it, almost smoky with some supplemented sweet honey and vanilla... Flavors are on point with a barrel  essence of light iodine and woody barrel characteristics. Sweet throughout but not overwhelmingly so. Body goes quite well with the style and substance if the brew with a soft to medium level of carbonation. A touch of whiskey heat on the backend which doesnt detract but adds character. Solid with a lot of added.

bottle... light black with a light tan head that is gone almost right away... the aroma is several aromas rounded into sweet note, light coffee, molasses, black licorice, and lots of bourbon... initially this just tastes like a blended batch of several bourbons, as it warms a really sweet and syrupy chocolate emerges, molasses, chocolate cake, smooth bourbon finish... really solid

Bottle This beer rocks! Dark brown ale with no head. The aroma is a super complex mélange of bourbon, dark chocolate, cinnamon, wildflower honey and loads of deeply roasted coffee. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and pillow-soft carbonation. The flavor is of sweet chocolate-covered black cherries, pronounced mocha and a gentle note of vanilla. Roasty, sweet, chocolate-drenched fruit finish. Big-time thanks to biggsbowler for sharing this rare treat!

Bottle shared by biggsbowler.  Dark brown pour with no head.  Coco puffs and winter spice aromas.  Not too thick with good lacing.  Smooth and delicious with coffee, honey, coco, dark roasted malt, and caramel notes.  Well done.....

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 (22oz bottle courtesy of dak).  Pours near black with thin espresso head. Aroma is heavy vegetal, chocolate, light bourbon.  Taste is sweet malts with chocolate and caramel.  Full bodied with oily texture.  Alcohol heat. Good.
Finally. Mostly black. Small tannish head. Aroma of smoke, spice, toasty malt, molasses. Flavor has loads of roast, molasses, smoke, charred oak. Wonderful.

Pour is pretty dark. Tan head, not super dense. Aroma is chocolate, cinnamon and vanilla. Very rich and warming. Maybe a hint of hazelnut. Really inviting and complex. Great. I definitely get the spices in the taste, gives it a little bit of a Christmas hot chocolate feel. Its almost like a hot chocolate coffee blend, which I happen to drink a lot and thus really like. There is a bit of chocolate and some booziness on the finish, but nothing harsh or biting. Very nice. Mouthfeel could be a bit better, but overall this is delicious.

500mL thanks to oteyj. Pours near ink, very black SRM generating a surprisingly fizzy, reddish tan head settling to a thin cappuccino froth. Sticky, webby tan lace. Nose is interesting. Sharp vanilla bean and ancho/guajillo chili pepper dark chocolate sprinkled with turbinado sugar. Wow. Soft bourbon spice. Subtle yet fantastic nose- must allow it to decant a little bit. Morphs to melted dark chocolate bar. Taste....wow. Very silky, soft, almost like drinking super dark chocolate milkshake. Wild palate. Hilariously soft- almost impossibly soft. Muted bourbon spice, buttery dark chocolate ganache, true French truffles melting. In the finish is mild barrel character. Palate is 6/5. I can see all those people at Dark Lord Day pooping in Port-A-Potties and reeking of BO waiting for 8 hours to try a beer that they think will taste like Hill Farmstead Birth of Tragedy, but sadly is Dark Lord. A 3.8 level imperial stout at best that trembles in the presence of this behemoth, which is devastating not only in aesthetics and taste but also in subtlety and softness. What a magical experience. I will say one thing: DO NOT AGE!! You will be wildly disappointed. This baby is good to go.

tried this multiple times now, bottles courtesy of shaun and ernesto. terrific bourbon importer, well rounded, lots of bourbon highlighted here very nicely. a bit sticky in the back palate, slightly bitter aftertaste shows up too, slightly drying. makes you want another fresh sip for the sweet bourbon profile. overall a very nice brew, a year or two on it may help a bit.

Outstanding beer.  Pours a silky smooth luxurious black pour with moderate to low carbonation.  Aroma is toasted vanilla, bourbon, roasted malts, bakers chocolate, and spices.  The taste is wonderful and I cant think of a better beer to be described as a winter beer.  Tons of bourbon and barrel character, almost too much.  Winner winner chicken dinner.

HUGE thanks to the man oteyj for picking up this gem!!! Thick black pour with a frothy, cask-like tan head. Nose is absolutely mindblowing, with epic notes of vanilla, dark cherry, uber rich chocolate ganache, mocha, and superb clove and cinnamon hidden in the depths. Further notes of dark rum, dark molasses and true New England maple syrup with that strong and genuine bark and nuanced sweetness. Both ends of the bourbon gamut also shine through; spicy rye and smooth wheat presence. Truly superb aroma. 



The flavor, if possible, might be better than the nose. The whiskey barrel comes through with even further vanilla extract, wood, spice, caramel, maple sap, chocolate truffle, smooth white chocolate latte, and even a touch of citrus, much like a chocolate orange. The mocha and lactic cream presence doesnt contribute any bitterness or roast, but just a supremely balanced, complex, and intricate sweetness. The barrel aging yields a creamier, richer, and smoother than most of Shauns beers; that crisp effervescence that marks most of Hill Farmsteads saisons, IPAs, and even his darker beers is replaced by a luxurious, smooth, wave-like texture that glides across the roof of the mouth, tongue, teeth, and gums with remarkable ease. The 11% ABV hardly shows, though there is a whisper of its presence, enough to make the fortitude of this beer felt in the deep reaches of the consumers mind. I am truly blown away. A marvel in the world of beer.

Thanks to a generous trading partner for sending this bottle. I wanted to share this but its my birthday and I wants it. 

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a thin mocha head that immediately fades into a thin ring. Not much in the way of lacing. 

Huge malt aroma thats bursting with roasted gourmet coffee, luscious chocolate and a strong barrel presence. Some prominent toasted oak along with sweet bourbon and vanilla notes followed by dark chocolate, oatmeal, coffee bean, dark fruit and toast. Complex and although the bourbon is strong, it doesnt overpower the other notes. 

Slightly viscous mouthfeel with a really nice balance of bourbon barrel, molasses, luscious chocolate, dark fruit and boozy heat. Really well balanced even though there is quite a bit of bourbon flavor. Dry toasted oak along with some sweet vanilla flavor and tons of delicious, sweet bourbon. Underneath, there is a nice molasses character that adds fullness to the palate along with a strong dark malt presence. Bittersweet dark chocolate complimented by a slightly roasted, incredibly smooth coffee flavor that never becomes acrid, astringent or harsh. Theres a decent amount of boozy heat in the finish but overall the high ABV is very well masked. 

Overall this beer is complex, well balanced and extremely flavorful. Its refreshing to find a beer like this that isnt a complete bourbon bomb. Recommended!
UPDATED: MAY 27, 2012 This is the best bourbon barrel aging Ive ever had. Huge complex bourbon flavors perfectly marries vanilla, roasted malts, with a long bourbon dry finish. Grand fuckin slam.

50cl bottle poured into a standard geuze tumbler. Inky black with a thin burgundy head. Nose is quite sweet...honey, black strap, dark fruits, a little barrel character. Taste mirrors the nose, coming off as overly sweet. Lots of residual sugars here. Notes of dark fruit, turbonado sugar, roasted malts, and slight oxidation. Not bad, but I would have liked to recognize more barrel character and roasted malts.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2012 tap at the brewery.   a bit hot at the moment.    potent oaky bourbon whiskey, vanilla, backed by some dark fruits, and milk chocolate. bourbon dominated all the nice, complex clean character of twilight.  prefer twilight of the idols, but this might improve with a touch of age as the barrel notes are a bit aggressive at the moment.       still pretty tasty though.   definitely not bad.   just preferred the twilight i had for breakfast this morning.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 On tap at HFS. This is without a doubt, one of the best barrel aged beers Ive ever had. Black and filthy pour with a medium sized tan head, that despite months of barrel aging, has excellent retention. The nose is out of control: vanilla bourbon, whiskey, milky chocolate, bakers chocolate, cocoa nib, brownies, caramel, back strap molasses, and subtle roast. The ethanol presence makes for a very hot beer, but it was just what the doctor ordered when I was standing in the cold outside the brewery. Palate is rich and thick- silky and supple with affirming booze and a desert like finish.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours an opaque black with a small, rough beige head. Soft and smooth yet intense Bourbony oak in the nose atop a layer of subtle roasted malt. Full-bodied with a soft carbonation, sweet roast, sweet licorice, plenty of vanilla and dried dark fruits - heavy on the dates and prunes. Again soft and pleasant Bourbon accents and a fairly warming alcohol in the finish without ever getting boozy. Very pleasant, very elegant. 161111

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2012 Served into a globe snifter at HFS. Pours a pitch black liquid and looks fairly viscous. only a few bubbles but no head forms. Smell begins with a rich chocolate roasty malt and coffee with lots of bourbon character, seeping with vanilla resins and a mild note of spice, cinnamon perhaps but not very distinguishable. Taste is a rich dark chocolate malt mocha with sweet vanilla notes and plenty of bourbon character. the spice notes are subtle and pleasant. spice notes open up as the liquid warms with the glass in my palm. Mouthfeel is full body rich feel with low carbonation that allows one to explore the flavors packed within. A touch of alcohol on the nose, not so much in taste and light  alcohol in the feel. Overall a rich flavorful beer that is wholly satisfying.

So sick.  On tap at the release for it.  Pours out a wonderful lush dark brown with bubbly coffee head.  Boozy aromas of vanilla and bourbon scream out the nose, sweetness abound.  Palate is light and fluffy, bourbon on the backshot, rich creamy textures up front and the abv is hidden so well.  Absolutely amazing, a new favorite.
On draft At the brewery.  Pitch black with a light tan head.  Bourbon and slight licorice.  Vanilla and light coffee chocolate notes.  Nice brew.

Bottled. A black beer with a thin Brown head. The aroma has notes of Wood, vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate, alcohol. The flavor has strong notes of roasted malt, bourbon, and alcohol, as Well as chocolate And vanilla, leading to a dry finish.  Thanks yespr for sharing.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2011 Pours a thick dark brown to black with a creamy, chocolate brown and lasting head. Aroma is smooth coffee, velvet bourbon with a touch of vanilla. Smooth, rich coffee, toffee, liqourice, vanilla and toasted dark malty flavoured. Velvet dark coffe malty and light bitter yet warming bourbon finish. Light vanilla touch. Extremely smooth and wellbalanced - best beer of 2011.
